message.content: This question requires knowledge of the lunar cycle. A new moon occurs approximately every 29.5 days, which is roughly equivalent to one month. Option (B) is incorrect because a new moon does not occur every week. Option (C) is incorrect because a new moon does not occur every day. Option (D) is incorrect because a new moon occurs more frequently than once a year.

This question requires basic knowledge about the lunar cycle. A new moon occurs approximately once a month. This is because a new moon happens when the sun and moon are in conjunction, meaning they are in the same direction in the sky. During this phase, the side of the moon facing the Earth is not illuminated by the sun, making it appear as if there is no moon visible in the night sky. Option (B) is incorrect because a new moon does not occur every week. Option (C) is incorrect because a new moon does not occur every day. Option (D) is incorrect because a new moon does not occur once a year.

Option (C) is too frequent, as there are usually several days between new moons. Option (D) is too infrequent, as multiple new moons can occur within a year.

During a new moon, the moon is positioned between Earth and the sun, so the illuminated side of the moon is facing away from us and appears invisible from Earth. Option (B) is too frequent of a time frame, as the moon goes through various phases within a month. Option (C) is too short of a time frame, as the moon takes longer than a day to go through its phases. Option (D) is too long of a time frame, as the moon goes through multiple cycles within a year.
